title: Are beards back to stay?
intro: Remember to subscribe to the podcast version !
this_week_question: What's the name for someone who loves beards? Is it...
a) barbophile? b) pogonophile? c) pelophile?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.
Remember to subscribe to the podcast version !

vocab.desc: join other people in doing something that has become popular - perhaps because you hope to become popular yourself
subject that a lot of people are discussing
when a condition or circumstance puts you in a favourable position
reached its highest point - and will decline from this point
women's struggle to achieve the same rights as men
a serious type of skin cancer

vocab.text: on board from the get go
vocab.desc: involvement with something right from the start

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hi there, Neil! Now, Neil... what's that on your face?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What… this? It's a beard, Rob. Have you never seen one before?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I have. But I've never seen one on you before… and I'm surprised to say, it looks good on you!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, thank you! I thought I'd get on the beard bandwagon, you know. Beards are all the rage at the moment - that means 'very fashionable'.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And to get on a bandwagon is when you join other people in doing something that has become popular – perhaps because you hope to become popular yourself!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that doesn't apply to me, Rob, because, as you know, I'm very popular already.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes. Yes, I know that, of course... Anyway, beards are such a talking point – a subject that a lot of people are discussing – that we decided to talk about them on today's programme! So are you ready for today's question, Neil? What's the name for someone who loves beards? Is it…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm. All the answers sound tempting. But I’m going to go for a) barbophile.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right. OK, well we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on. But this is interesting: a new scientific study suggests that the more beards there are in a population, the less attractive they become – and this currently gives clean-shaven men a competitive advantage.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, no! That's bad news for me, then! Competitive advantage means when a condition or circumstance puts you in a favourable position – in this case, being clean-shaven or having no facial hair.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's right. We’ve reached 'peak beard' apparently. Beard popularity has peaked – or reached its highest point – and will decline in popularity from this point.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. Let's listen to writer, Lucinda Hawksley, talking about beards through history. And listen out for a word that means women's struggle to achieve the same rights and opportunities as men.

transcript.author: Lucinda Hawksley, writer of Moustaches, Whiskers and Beards
transcript.text: It's interesting, while I was writing the book I came to realize that the most heavily bearded times in Britain are either when women are in power, such as Elizabeth I or Queen Victoria, or when there's a big discussion of feminism - and it is really interesting that in the last few years there's been so much more discussion of feminism. You get a woman on the throne and men go, 'Oh, got to have a beard.' It's really strange. Or in the 60s or 70s with all the kind of, you know, big thing about women's lib, suddenly the beard becomes huge here.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, needless to say Lucinda doesn't have a beard, but she certainly knows a lot about them. She's the great great granddaughter of famous writer Charles Dickens, who sported – or wore – a very flamboyant beard. Flamboyant means eye-catching and different.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, did you spot the word for women's struggle to achieve the same rights as men?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes. It's feminism . She also talks about women's lib , which is short for women's liberation. And this has a similar meaning to feminism. So, what do you think, Neil? Are beards a show of testosterone in reaction to powerful women? Is that why you've grown your beard?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I don't think it's testosterone – that's the main male hormone. For me, it's laziness. I'm flying the flag for men's lib – liberation from the razor.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right. Well, I'm not sure whether that's a worthy cause or not, Neil. Let's hear from Brock Elbank, the photographer behind the exhibition 'Beard'. He’s talking about one of the people he photographed.

transcript.author: Brock Elbank, photographer
transcript.text: I found Jimmy on a friend's Facebook page whilst I was in Sydney. Invited him to come to my home studio for a portrait and I posted it and it got reblogged over half a million times in four hours. I mean I think when Jimmy and I… when I met Jimmy he told me about his 'beard season' melanoma charity and I was kind of on board from the get go.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So Jimmy must have a pretty awesome beard!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Indeed. We should check out the Beard exhibition and find out. But Jimmy has a beard for a special reason, right Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right. Yes. Brock mentions Jimmy's melanoma charity. Melanoma is a serious type of skin cancer and Jimmy is raising money and awareness to help people who suffer from it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And Brock says he was on board from the get go – meaning he wanted to be involved with the charity right from the start.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We should also mention 'Movember' and 'Decembeard' – both campaigns invite men to get hairy for good causes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's right, good causes – moustaches in November and beards in December. Now, let's have the answer to the quiz question. I asked: what's the name for someone who loves beards. Was it: a) barbophile b) pogonopile or c) pelophile?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said a) barbophile.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Wrong, I'm afraid. The answer is actually b) pogonophile.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, well, you can't win them all. Now then, Rob, can we hear today's words again?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Sure. We heard:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. We hope it wasn't too hair-raising for you. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
